bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, August 4, 1920

div1.p: Carter writes about life in Peru and his field work. He discusses his health and financial matters as well.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, August 4, 1920
div1.p:
The more I reflect on “Dear Brutus”
the more I am convinced that “a
daughter's the thing” after all. Barrie
is dead right.

I hope you rec'd my letter - which sh'd
have left here on the Grace boat July 30
or 31. & I rather expect you did- It ask advis
advised you to direct all my mail
to me- Care of “The Foundation Company
No 332, Calle Rifa. Lima Peru”. They will
send it by hand to Paita & it will either
await me there or come by hand to
Piura. So I will get it, not soon promptly
it
2
it may be but with some degree of certainty

This letter also should reach you. It is
going up with Mrs Grubbs - on the 6th - & be
mailed in Balboa. On this account
I repeat the direction

I have had rather a long search for a yel-
low Vicuña rug. Bought one (£P.10,=$47.60/100)
in a somewhat dark store which I thought
matched the sample- It did not - was brown
rather than yellow, went over several stores
all the same in the good light. Finally con-
went to the same store - the largest dealer
here - & as soon as the proprietor saw my
sample - he said. It is from Bolivia. It is
dyed - nearly all Bolivian skins are dyed”. He
showed me that the leather was yellowish
not
3
not white like that of his skins, I traded for
one nearly yellow, as I am convinced that
he is right & that I can find no yellow skins
in Lima, & I cannot well go to La Paz - or mall
Mollendo. You can then do (1) have this
skin died to match or (2) have a border
made of this skin - using the pieces thus saved
from your coat to renew it where needed
It - the one I have is a good skin - short & pury
not like wool. I had a great notion to take
a very pale skin - on account of its beautiful
texture - which used the same way would
only make a border more contrasting than
this one. However - I didn't - You have a nice
rug - not the color you wish but which I think
can be made to serve your purpose. Indeed
4
Indeed you will have enough to make a-
nother coat when this one wears out. If you
want me I can when I get ready to return get
yet another - rug-picking it for its texture-not
its color. If such a rug would be pale-light
browns browns & white & cream - & would make a
very pretty fur, coat or anything else to wear,
Basta dell de las Vicuñas- They are beautiful
however & less raised - than other things- This
one had been 7 £.P. 7.00 in /14.

My I have had some trouble with my “Kink”- not
severe, as I know better how to manage it, but
it is depressing. Have had not for the past 3
days & do hope to have a rest from it.

My business is not quite settled yet - all of
last week except Monday was a fiesta our
business done. I have put in a long Informe
5
Informe, on the condition of the Northern pro-
vinces as regards Y. F. & have to combat-the
unreasonable optimism of these people now as
I had to fight their unreasonable pessi-
mism in March & April. Fortunately a
few cases case occured for case was
reported - found dead - in Chulucanas
a few days ago & I had it expressed an opin- the
predicted that it was not over at that town
I have more honor than a prophet generally
gets. I put in my expense account $393,
$ 393. & $ 150 sales - which I sh'd get shortly
- within a week- Hanson says.
Have $200, in bank & about $25 in my pocket.

I will meet the President this afternoon
afternoon & am glad of it, I want to deal
with him directly as much as possible
not through the Jefe de la Sulubridad-
Dr. Cardenas.

I do not know, yet whether I will go up to
Paita on the 6, with Grubbs or not. My pur-
pose for there to take the northern provinces -
Piura & Tumbez - & leave Hanson to run
the work here Mrs H. greatly approves this
program- Probably Either we both. (H &I.) go
up on the 6. Hanson arrange some de-
tails - which he ought to arrange - dispu-
ted accounts & other rows - & then return
here leaving me at Piura which sh'd
be the head quarters of the work in the
north. He would remain about 14 days &
continue his work here.
Else Hanson will go by himself- I con-
ducting & attending to his work here
When he has his disputes settled - 8 days
& 4 days time in transit.- I go north - settle matters
8/ 7
with him, & let him return. The s last
in first is the best for the y. f. work: the last
best for the Lima work & nearly the same for
the y. f. work. & I think will be what is done,
I really don't much care but perfor the first
I will probably - certainly - be able to put in
this letter what which plan will be followed.

I am in better spirits etc than when I last
wrote- Adios hasta mañana and quando
voy à acabar esta Carta
div1.closer:
Su Padre que te Ama H. R. Carter P.S.I am speaking Spanish quite fluently
but less fluently than incorrectly.
C

div1.p:
I am wearing my ordinary winter clothes! Two
pair of heavy drawers: one heavy flannel shirt
over a B.V.D. & my grey cheriot suit: when I put
on my tail coat - Oxford grey - which is lighter but more
dressy than the grey. I put on my spiral put-
tees over around my legs above the knees &
also the sweater under my shirt! It is
not specially cold - only there are no fires &
I am cold unless I dress as I have said
naturally I keep warm- It is about
5° to 7° or 10° warmer in Piura & Paita

I saw the President yesterday afternoon - but the
interview was too short to be satisfactory. I purpose
to see him again. Hanson goes tomorrow
to Paita- I purpose to follow him- in about 7
days. Little time will be thus last - about 3 or 4
days only which will be paid for by my work here.
On the return yesterday- my pocket was picked
I lost my watch. Bought another - $5 90/100 - on
1
B23
Ingers all this morning. I am sorry, as the
one I had - Clarence's was a good worth-al-
though not an expensive one.

Aileen says -sent word- she has two letters from you. I will go to
see her this evening to hear them. I pretty
surely have some at Payta - which I will
get when I go there. I am anxious to get them &
go in as that work. I will feel more as if I were
justifying my service.

Aug 6: saw your letters(July 4 & 8) & one of Henry's. Hanson leaves
am well - love to all
today- I about the 12th (if the Vessel is ontime), & especially give my
most sincere sympathy to Mrs Gorgas. I am in-
clined to think that except what I stay. f: campaign the
sanitation in Peru will come to nothing. Possibly
some malarial work can be done. I do not know,
